text.text: Data Ethics Considerations

Throughout the ERB process, the core team and workshop participants collaborate to gather information or data about their community. They visualize and analyze this information (e.g., using indicator card sorting) to assess hazards, equity, and resilience. This information is vital for understanding community needs and identifying actions to take. However, it is important that the core team approach this issue with care by observing data ethics.
What are data ethics?

Data ethics are principles and practices to generate, collect, administer, store, share, and use information or data [1, 2, 3]. In western science, this concept is codified in Belmont Forum principles and federal rules for human subjects research. In ERB, the term is used in a broader sense of how the core team and its partners can carry out data actions in ways that:
Do no harm
and
minimize burdens
to those involved or other groups
• Provide short and long-term
in a fair and just way
Offer equal opportunities
for making contributions
• Provide
informed choices
to solicit
voluntary participation
• Respect and uphold cultural worldviews and
forms of knowledge
Accept boundaries
about what people are willing to share
• Be careful stewards of
privacy and confidentiality
• Acknowledge
Indigenous data sovereignty

Data ethics are necessary because historically, Black, Indigenous, people of color, and other socially marginalized populations in the United States have experienced extractive science that provided no benefit to them and even caused direct harm. These legacies of unethical actions affect how even the most well-intentioned requests for information for resilience planning are viewed in some communities.

Following data ethics can enhance the value of information for resilience planning and strengthen community connections. Failure to do so can undermine relationships and trust. It can also lead to difficulties for community residents, businesses, and organizations.
Institutional requirements

Core team members may need to follow specific legal or institutional requirements regarding data, including local knowledge. The information gathered as part of the ERB process is geared to supporting decision-making, not scientific research per se. It does not entail gathering data about people to produce generalizable knowledge. Rules for human subjects research may not be applicable. Nevertheless, depending on their institution’s policies, university scientists on the core team might still have to coordinate with their Institutional Review Board. Federal, Tribal, and state government employees might be bound by other data protocol.

Indigenous Knowledge and Data Sovereignty
Indigenous Data Sovereignty draws on the
United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP)
, which reaffirms the rights of Indigenous Peoples to control data about their peoples, lands, and resources. The
CARE Principles for Indigenous Data Governance
address Collective benefit, Authority to control, Responsibility, and Ethics [4].

Federal guidance on Indigenous Knowledges recognizes its value and offers guidelines on how to ethically and respectfully work with Indigenous people and Tribal and Indian Nations to include Indigenous Knowledges in decision-making [5]. State, county, and municipal governments may have their own guidance and policies for working with sovereign Tribal nations and Indigenous Peoples.
Collective benefit
is more likely to be realized when data ecosystems are designed to support Indigenous nations and when the use/reuse of data for resource allocation is consistent with community values.
UNDRIP asserts Indigenous Peoples’ rights and interests in data and their
authority to control
their data. Access to ‘data for governance’ is vital to support self-determination and Indigenous nations should be actively involved in ‘governance of data’ to ensure ethical reuse of data.
Data collectors have a
responsibility

to engage respectfully with indigenous communities to ensure the use of Indigenous Knowledges supports capacity development, increasing community data capabilities, and the strengthening of Indigenous languages and cultures.
Similarly,
ethics
grounded in Indigenous Peoples’ worldviews should inform the use of data across time in order to minimize harm, maximize benefits, promote justice, and allow for future use.
When working with sovereign Tribal nations and Indigenous communities, it is vital to discuss and agree on how ethical data principles will be implemented and to check-in regularly.
